        17. 17
          Hatcher, E.; Soudackov, A. V.; Hammes-Schiffer, S. Proton-Coupled Electron Transfer in Soybean Lipoxygenase. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2004, 126, 5763– 5775,  DOI: 10.1021/ja039606o
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          17
          Proton-Coupled Electron Transfer in Soybean Lipoxygenase
          Hatcher, Elizabeth; Soudackov, Alexander V.; Hammes-Schiffer, Sharon
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (18), 5763-5775CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          The proton-coupled electron transfer reaction catalyzed by soybean lipoxygenase-1 is studied with a multistate continuum theory that represents the transferring hydrogen nucleus as a quantum mech. wave function. The inner-sphere reorganization energy of the iron cofactor is calcd. with d. functional theory, and the outer-sphere reorganization energy of the protein is calcd. with the frequency-resolved cavity model for conformations obtained with docking simulations. Both classical and quantum mech. treatments of the proton donor-acceptor vibrational motion are presented. The temp. dependence of the calcd. rates and kinetic isotope effects is in agreement with the exptl. data. The weak temp. dependence of the rates is due to the relatively small free energy barrier arising from a balance between the reorganization energy and the reaction free energy. The unusually high deuterium kinetic isotope effect of 81 is due to the small overlap of the reactant and product proton vibrational wave functions and the dominance of the lowest energy reactant and product vibronic states in the tunneling process. The temp. dependence of the kinetic isotope effect is strongly influenced by the proton donor-acceptor distance with the dominant contribution to the overall rate. This dominant proton donor-acceptor distance is significantly smaller than the equil. donor-acceptor distance and is detd. by a balance between the larger coupling and the smaller Boltzmann probability as the distance decreases. Thus, the proton donor-acceptor vibrational motion plays a vital role in decreasing the dominant donor-acceptor distance relative to its equil. value to facilitate the proton-coupled electron transfer reaction.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXjt1Ghur8%253D&md5=c3de26943ff2aa6ef66769aba01d26ca
          open URL
        18. 18
          Glickman, M. H.; Klinman, J. P. Nature of Rate-Limiting Steps in the Soybean Lipoxygenase-1 Reaction. Biochemistry 1995, 34, 14077– 14092,  DOI: 10.1021/bi00043a013
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          18
          Nature of Rate-Limiting Steps in the Soybean Lipoxygenase-1 Reaction
          Glickman, Michael H.; Klinman, Judith P.
          Biochemistry (1995), 34 (43), 14077-92CODEN: BICHAW; ISSN:0006-2960. (American Chemical Society)
          A series of kinetic isotope effect expts. were performed with the goal of understanding the nature of rate-limiting steps in the soybean lipoxygenase-1 (SBL-1) reaction. SBL-1 was reacted with linoleic acid (LA) and deuterated linoleic acid (D-LA) under a variety of exptl. conditions involving changes in temp., pH, viscosity, and replacement of H2O with D2O. The extrapolated intrinsic primary H/D isotope effect can be estd. to be possibly as large as 80. This value is probably the largest effect published for an enzymic reaction, and much larger than that predicted from semiclassical models. Due to this large primary isotope effect, the C-D bond cleavage fully limits the rate of reaction under all conditions tested. In the case of protonated linoleic acid, a no. of steps are partially rate-limiting at room temp.; three distinct mechanistic steps which include substrate binding, an H2O/D2O sensitive step, and C-H bond cleavage have been characterized. Use of glucose as a solvent viscosogen demonstrates that substrate binding is approx. 48% rate-limiting for LA at 20°. SBL-1 is one of the few enzymes that fit the definition of a "perfect enzyme", in the sense that further optimization of any single step at room temp. will not significantly increase the overall rate. At lower temps., the step sensitive to solvent deuteration begins to dominate the reaction, whereas at higher temps., the hydrogen abstraction step is rate-limiting. The pH dependence of kcat/Km for SBL-1 can be explained as arising from two pKa's, one controlling substrate binding and the other substrate release. Below pH 7.8, the rate of substrate release increases, thus decreasing the commitment to catalysis and unmasking the large intrinsic isotope effect on the subsequent hydrogen abstraction. An abnormally high pKa, in the range of 7-8, has been detd. for LA in the concn. range employed in these studies. The authors propose that the neg. charged form of LA, predominating above pH 7.8, is the preferred substrate with larger commitments to catalysis.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXos1Wms7c%253D&md5=1bce6fa8366f7a36f5196031d68f0e1a
          open URL
        19. 19
          Glickman, M. H.; Wiseman, J. S.; Klinman, J. P. Extremely Large Isotope Effects in the Soybean Lipoxygenase-Linoleic Acid Reaction. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1994, 116, 793– 794,  DOI: 10.1021/ja00081a060
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          19
          Extremely Large Isotope Effects in the Soybean Lipoxygenase-Linoleic Acid Reaction
          Glickman, Michael H.; Wiseman, Jeffrey S.; Klinman, Judith P.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (1994), 116 (2), 793-4CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
          Very large primary deuterium isotope effects are obsd. for the oxidn. of linoleic acid by lipoxygenase. Primary kinetic (kH/kD) isotope effects were measured both competitively and noncompetitively, with substrates synthesized by different methods and under different conditions. At room temp. and pH 9, comparing linoleic acid to [11,11-2H2]linoleic acid shows a D(V) = 43.4 (±1.9) and D(V/K) = 27.4 (±3.8). In all cases an upper limit of ca. 60 was obtained for the isotope effects by changing reaction conditions. These seem to be the largest published primary (kH/kD) isotope effects in an enzymic system.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2cXnt1aksg%253D%253D&md5=b59c096f56bfa2d1102bebb63c5c8258
          open URL
        20. 20
          Jonsson, T.; Glickman, M. H.; Sun, S. J.; Klinman, J. P. Experimental Evidence for Extensive Tunneling of Hydrogen in the Lipoxygenase Reaction: Implications for Enzyme Catalysis. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1996, 118, 10319– 10320,  DOI: 10.1021/ja961827p
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          20
          Experimental Evidence for Extensive Tunneling of Hydrogen in the Lipoxygenase Reaction: Implications for Enzyme Catalysis
          Jonsson, Thorlakur; Glickman, Michael H.; Sun, Shujun; Klinman, Judith P.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (1996), 118 (42), 10319-10320CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          Hydrogen tunneling has recently has been shown to take place in the enzyme-catalyzed hydrogen transfer reactions of yeast alc. dehydrogenase, horse liver alc. dehydrogenase, bovine serum amine oxidase, and monoamine oxidase B. In all cases, the obsd. behavior is consistent with the view of a tunneling correction to the reaction rate, such that the lighter isotopes of hydrogen undergo tunneling to a greater extent than the heavier ones. Recent investigations of steady state kinetic isotope effects in the soybean lipoxygenase reaction have indicated the largest deuterium isotope effect seen for a biol. catalyst (kH/kD = 48 at 25°). Extension of these measurements to single turnover conditions supports the view that the enormous rate discrimination between hydrogen and deuterium occurs in the C-H bond activation step. Measurement of the temp. dependence for C-H(D) cleavage under both pre-steady state and steady state conditions reveals a nearly activationless process. The combined observation of very small enthalpies of activation and very large, nearly temp.-independent isotope effects leads us to conclude that soybean lipoxygenase facilitates the loss of hydrogen from substrate near room temp. by invoking extensive tunneling. This type of behavior has been seen with small mols., but generally only at very low temps. A diagram is presented to encompass the observe range of enzymic behavior, in which tunneling varies from moderate to extensive. As predicted, a correlation can be obsd. between enzymic enthalpies of activation and the magnitude of isotope effects on Arrhenius prefactors. These results indicate that optimal catalytic efficiency in enzyme reactions requires a modulation of reaction barrier width as well as height.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK28XmtFKks7w%253D&md5=2d3e621a9c0194942cab4f8ec21c67f3
          open URL
        21. 21
          Knapp, M. J.; Rickert, K.; Klinman, J. P. Temperature-Dependent Isotope Effects in Soybean Lipoxygenase-1: Correlating Hydrogen Tunneling with Protein Dynamics. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2002, 124, 3865– 3874,  DOI: 10.1021/ja012205t
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          21
          Temperature-Dependent Isotope Effects in Soybean Lipoxygenase-1: Correlating Hydrogen Tunneling with Protein Dynamics
          Knapp, Michael J.; Rickert, Keith; Klinman, Judith P.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2002), 124 (15), 3865-3874CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          The hydrogen-atom transfer in soybean lipoxygenase-1 (SLO) exhibits a large kinetic isotope effect on kcat (KIE = 81) near room temp. and a very weak temp. dependence (Eact = 2.1 kcal/mol). These properties are consistent with H· transfer that occurs entirely by a tunneling event. Mutants of SLO were prepd., and the temp. dependence of the KIE was measured, to test for alterations in the tunneling behavior. All mutants studied exhibit KIEs of similar, large magnitude at 30°, despite an up to 3 orders of magnitude change in kcat. Eact for two of the mutants (Leu754 → Ala, Leu546 → Ala) is larger than for wild-type (WT), and the KIE becomes slightly more temp. dependent. In contrast, Ile553 → Ala exhibits kcat and Eact parameters similar to wild-type soybean lipoxygenase-1 (WT-SLO) for protiated substrate; however, the KIE is markedly temp. dependent. The behavior of the former two mutants could reflect increased reorganization energies (λ), but the behavior of the latter mutant is inconsistent with this description. We have invoked a full H· tunneling model (Kuznetsov, A. M.; Ulstrup, J. Can. J. Chem. 1999, 77, 1085-1096) to explain the temp. dependence of the KIE, which is indicative of the extent to which distance sampling (gating) modulates hydrogen transfer. WT-SLO exhibits a very small Eact and a nearly temp.-independent KIE, which was modeled as arising from a compressed hydrogen transfer distance with little modulation of the hydrogen transfer distance. The observations on the Leu754 → Ala and Leu546 → Ala mutants were modeled as arising from a slightly less compressed active site with greater modulation of the hydrogen transfer distance by environmental dynamics. Finally, the obsd. behavior of the Ile553 → Ala mutant indicates a relaxed active site with extensive involvement of gating to facilitate hydrogen transfer. We conclude that WT-SLO has an active site structure that is well organized to support hydrogen tunneling and that mutations perturb structural elements that support hydrogen tunneling. Modest alterations in active site residues increase λ and/or increase the hydrogen transfer distance, thereby affecting the probability that tunneling can occur. These studies allow the detection and characterization of a protein-gating mode in catalysis.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XitVKqurg%253D&md5=e63570c9ed25cd5d141ecee52583487b
          open URL
        22. 22
          Soudackov, A. V.; Hammes-Schiffer, S. Proton-Coupled Electron Transfer Reactions: Analytical Rate Constants and Case Study of Kinetic Isotope Effects in Lipoxygenase. Faraday Discuss. 2016, 195, 171– 189,  DOI: 10.1039/C6FD00122J
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          22
          Proton-coupled electron transfer reactions: analytical rate constants and case study of kinetic isotope effects in lipoxygenase
          Soudackov, Alexander V.; Hammes-Schiffer, Sharon
          Faraday Discussions (2016), 195 (Reaction Rate Theory), 171-189CODEN: FDISE6; ISSN:1359-6640. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          A general theory has been developed for proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET), which is vital to a wide range of chem. and biol. processes. This theory describes PCET reactions in terms of nonadiabatic transitions between reactant and product electron-proton vibronic states and includes the effects of thermal fluctuations of the solvent or protein environment, as well as the proton donor-acceptor motion. Within the framework of this general PCET theory, a series of anal. rate const. expressions has been derived for PCET reactions in well-defined regimes. Herein, the application of this theory to PCET in the enzyme soybean lipoxygenase illustrates the regimes of validity for the various rate const. expressions and elucidates the fundamental phys. principles dictating PCET reactions. Such theor. studies provide significant phys. insights that guide the interpretation of exptl. data and lead to exptl. testable predictions. A combination of theor. treatments with at.-level simulations is essential to understanding PCET.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XpsVOlsb0%253D&md5=103341468cac8348e786883eee5b1a72
          open URL
        23. 23
          Hatcher, E.; Soudackov, A. V.; Hammes-Schiffer, S. Proton-Coupled Electron Transfer in Soybean Lipoxygenase: Dynamical Behavior and Temperature Dependence of Kinetic Isotope Effects. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2007, 129, 187– 196,  DOI: 10.1021/ja0667211
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          23
          Proton-Coupled Electron Transfer in Soybean Lipoxygenase: Dynamical Behavior and Temperature Dependence of Kinetic Isotope Effects
          Hatcher, Elizabeth; Soudackov, Alexander V.; Hammes-Schiffer, Sharon
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (1), 187-196CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          The dynamical behavior and the temp. dependence of the kinetic isotope effects (KIEs) are examd. for the proton-coupled electron transfer reaction catalyzed by the enzyme soybean lipoxygenase. The calcns. are based on a vibronically nonadiabatic formulation that includes the quantum mech. effects of the active electrons and the transferring proton, as well as the motions of all atoms in the complete solvated enzyme system. The rate const. is represented by the time integral of a probability flux correlation function that depends on the vibronic coupling and on time correlation functions of the energy gap and the proton donor-acceptor mode, which can be calcd. from classical mol. dynamics simulations of the entire system. The dynamical behavior of the probability flux correlation function is dominated by the equil. protein and solvent motions and is not significantly influenced by the proton donor-acceptor motion. The magnitude of the overall rate is strongly influenced by the proton donor-acceptor frequency, the vibronic coupling, and the protein/solvent reorganization energy. The calcns. reproduce the exptl. obsd. magnitude and temp. dependence of the KIE for the soybean lipoxygenase reaction without fitting any parameters directly to the exptl. kinetic data. The temp. dependence of the KIE is detd. predominantly by the proton donor-acceptor frequency and the distance dependence of the vibronic couplings for hydrogen and deuterium. The ratio of the overlaps of the hydrogen and deuterium vibrational wavefunctions strongly impacts the magnitude of the KIE but does not significantly influence its temp. dependence. For this enzyme reaction, the large magnitude of the KIE arises mainly from the dominance of tunneling between the ground vibronic states and the relatively large ratio of the overlaps between the corresponding hydrogen and deuterium vibrational wavefunctions. The weak temp. dependence of the KIE is due in part to the dominance of the local component of the proton donor-acceptor motion.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xhtlaju73N&md5=63db97f6cd817adf179e0a9cc71fc3c3
          open URL
        24. 24
          Edwards, S. J.; Soudackov, A. V.; Hammes-Schiffer, S. Impact of Distal Mutation on Hydrogen Transfer Interface and Substrate Conformation in Soybean Lipoxygenase. J. Phys. Chem. B 2010, 114, 6653– 6660,  DOI: 10.1021/jp100133p
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          24
          Impact of Distal Mutation on Hydrogen Transfer Interface and Substrate Conformation in Soybean Lipoxygenase
          Edwards, Sarah J.; Soudackov, Alexander V.; Hammes-Schiffer, Sharon
          Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2010), 114 (19), 6653-6660CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1520-6106. (American Chemical Society)
          The impact of distal mutation on the hydrogen transfer interface properties and on the substrate mobility, conformation, and orientation in soybean lipoxygenase-1 (SLO) is examd. SLO catalyzes a hydrogen abstraction reaction that occurs by a proton-coupled electron transfer mechanism. Mutation of isoleucine 553 to less bulky residues has been found exptl. to increase the magnitude and temp. dependence of the kinetic isotope effect for this reaction. This residue borders the linoleic acid substrate but is ∼15 Å from the active site iron. In the present study, we model these exptl. data with a vibronically nonadiabatic theory and perform all-atom mol. dynamics simulations on the complete solvated wild-type and mutant enzymes. Our calcns. indicate that the proton transfer equil. distance increases and the assocd. frequency decreases as residue 553 becomes less bulky. The mol. dynamics simulations illustrate that this mutation impacts the mobility, geometrical conformation, and orientation of the linoleic acid within the active site. In turn, these effects alter the proton donor-acceptor equil. distance and frequency, leading to the exptl. obsd. changes in the magnitude and temp. dependence of the kinetic isotope effect. This study provides insight into how the effects of distal mutations may be transmitted in enzymes to ultimately impact the catalytic rates.

          Meyer, M. P.; Tomchick, D. R.; Klinman, J. P. Enzyme Structure and Dynamics Affect Hydrogen Tunneling: The Impact of a Remote Side Chain (1553) in Soybean Lipoxygenase-1. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2008, 105, 1146– 1151,  DOI: 10.1073/pnas.0710643105
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          26
          Enzyme structure and dynamics affect hydrogen tunneling: The impact of a remote side chain (I553) in soybean lipoxygenase-1
          Meyer, Matthew P.; Tomchick, Diana R.; Klinman, Judith P.
          Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2008), 105 (4), 1146-1151, S1146/1-S1146/12CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
          This study examines the impact of a series of mutations at position 553 on the kinetic and structural properties of soybean lipoxygenase-1 (SLO-1). The previously uncharacterized mutants reported herein are I553L, I553V, and I553G. High-resoln. x-ray studies of these mutants, together with the earlier studied I553A, show almost no structural change in relation to the WT-enzyme. By contrast, a progression in kinetic behavior occurs in which the decrease in the size of the side chain at position 553 leads to an increased importance of donor-acceptor distance sampling in the course of the hydrogen transfer process. These dynamical changes in behavior are interpreted in the context of two general classes of protein motions, preorganization and reorganization, with the latter including the distance sampling modes. The aggregate data for SLO-1 show how judicious placement of hydrophobic side chains can influence enzyme catalysis via enhanced donor-acceptor hydro-genic wave function overlap.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhs1KmtLw%253D&md5=9a5a789879adba5216bab4822f4ad9a4

          Meyer, M. P.; Klinman, J. P. Modeling Temperature Dependent Kinetic Isotope Effects for Hydrogen Transfer in a Series of Soybean Lipoxygenase Mutants: The Effect of Anharmonicity Upon Transfer Distance. Chem. Phys. 2005, 319, 283– 296,  DOI: 10.1016/j.chemphys.2005.05.017
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          27
          Modeling temperature dependent kinetic isotope effects for hydrogen transfer in a series of soybean lipoxygenase mutants: The effect of anharmonicity upon transfer distance
          Meyer, Matthew P.; Klinman, Judith P.
          Chemical Physics (2005), 319 (1-3), 283-296CODEN: CMPHC2; ISSN:0301-0104. (Elsevier B.V.)
          Soybean lipoxygenase-1 (SLO) catalyzes the oxidn. of linoleic acid. The rate-limiting step in this transformation is the net abstraction of the pro-S hydrogen atom from the center of the 1,5-pentadienyl moiety in linoleic acid. The large deuterium kinetic isotope effect (KIE) for this step appears in the first order rate const. (Dkcat = 81±5 at T = 25°). Furthermore, the KIE and the rate for protium abstraction are weakly temp. dependent (EA,D - EA,H = 0.9±0.2 kcal/mol and EA,H = 2.1±0.2 kcal/mol, resp.). Mutations at a hydrophobic site about 13 Å from the active site Fe(III), Ile553, induce a marked temp. dependence that varies roughly in accordance with the degree to which the residue is changed in bulk from the wild type Ile. While the temp. dependence for these mutants varies from the wild type enzyme, the magnitude of the KIE at 25° is on the same order of magnitude. A hydrogen tunneling model [Kuznetsov, A. M., Ulstrup, J. Can. J. Chem. 77 (1999) 1085-1096] is utilized to model the KIE temp. profiles for the wild type SLO and each Ile553 mutant. Hydrogenic wavefunctions are modeled using harmonic oscillators and Morse oscillators in order to explore the effects of anharmonicity upon computed kinetic observables used to characterize this hydrogen transfer.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXht1Ort7zL&md5=fc46ef4a3f7b45c2c5ec1dd44ac3c2ca

          Hu, S.; Soudackov, A. V.; Hammes-Schiffer, S.; Klinman, J. P. Enhanced Rigidification within a Double Mutant of Soybean Lipoxygenase Provides Experimental Support for Vibronically Nonadiabatic Proton-Coupled Electron Transfer Models.           [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          28
          Enhanced rigidification within a double mutant of soybean lipoxygenase provides experimental support for vibronically nonadiabatic proton-coupled electron transfer models
          Hu, Shenshen; Soudackov, Alexander V.; Hammes-Schiffer, Sharon; Klinman, Judith P.
          ACS Catalysis (2017), 7 (5), 3569-3574CODEN: ACCACS; ISSN:2155-5435. (American Chemical Society)
          Soybean lipoxygenase (SLO) is a prototype for nonadiabatic hydrogen tunneling reactions and, as such, has served as the subject of numerous theor. studies. Here, we report a nearly temp.-independent kinetic isotope effect (KIE) with an av. KIE value of 661 ± 27 for a double mutant (DM) of SLO at 6 temps. The data were well-reproduced within a vibronically nonadiabatic proton-coupled electron transfer model in which the active site became rigidified compared to the wild-type enzyme and single-site mutants. A combined temp.-pressure perturbation further showed that temp.-dependent global motions within DM-SLO were more resistant to perturbation by elevated pressure. These findings provided strong exptl. support for the model of hydrogen tunneling in SLO, where optimization of both local protein and ligand motions and distal conformational rearrangements is a prerequisite for effective proton vibrational wave function overlap between the substrate and the active site Fe cofactor.

          Hu, S.; Sharma, S. C.; Scouras, A. D.; Soudackov, A. V.; Carr, C. A. M.; Hammes-Schiffer, S.; Alber, T.; Klinman, J. P. Extremely Elevated Room-Temperature Kinetic Isotope Effects Quantify the Critical Role of Barrier Width in Enzymatic C-H Activation. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2014, 136, 8157– 8160,  DOI: 10.1021/ja502726s
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          29
          Extremely elevated room-temperature kinetic isotope effects quantify the critical role of barrier width in enzymatic C-H activation
          Hu, Shenshen; Sharma, Sudhir C.; Scouras, Alexander D.; Soudackov, Alexander V.; Carr, Cody A. Marcus; Hammes-Schiffer, Sharon; Alber, Tom; Klinman, Judith P.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136 (23), 8157-8160CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          Soybean lipoxygenase (I) has served as a prototype for H-tunneling reactions, as a result of its unusual kinetic isotope effects (KIEs) and their temp. dependencies. Here, using a synergy of kinetic, structural, and theor. studies, the authors show how the interplay between donor-acceptor distance and active site flexibility leads to catalytic behavior previously predicted by quantum tunneling theory. Modification of the size of 2 hydrophobic residues by site-specific mutagenesis in I reduced the reaction rate 104-fold and was accompanied by an enormous and unprecedented room-temp. KIE. Fitting of the kinetic data to a non-adiabatic model implicated an expansion of the active site that could not be compensated by donor-acceptor distance sampling. A 1.7 Å resoln. x-ray structure of the double mutant further indicated an unaltered backbone conformation, almost identical side-chain conformations, and a significantly enlarged active site cavity. These findings show the compelling property of room-temp. H-tunneling within a biol. context and demonstrate the very high sensitivity of such tunneling to barrier width.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXptVaht7Y%253D&md5=8f826611721093d5b32fc8f5b847aeef

        30. 30
          Klinman, J. K.; Offenbacher, A. R. Understanding Biological Hydrogen Transfer through the Lens of Temperature Dependent Kinetic Isotope Effects. Acc. Chem. Res. 2018, 51, 1966– 1974,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.accounts.8b00226
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          30
          Understanding Biological Hydrogen Transfer Through the Lens of Temperature Dependent Kinetic Isotope Effects
          Klinman, Judith P.; Offenbacher, Adam R.
          Accounts of Chemical Research (2018), 51 (9), 1966-1974CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
          Hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) is a salient feature of many enzymic C-H cleavage mechanisms. In systems where kinetic isolation of HAT is achieved, selective labeling of substrate with hydrogen isotopes, such as deuterium, enables the detn. of intrinsic kinetic isotope effects (KIEs). While the magnitude of the KIE is itself informative, ultimately the size of the temp. dependence of the KIE, ΔEa = Ea(D)-Ea(H), serves as a crit., and often misinterpreted (or even ignored) descriptor of the reaction coordinate. As will be highlighted in this Accounts, ΔEa is one of the most robust parameters to emerge from studies of enzyme catalyzed hydrogen transfer. Kinetic parameters for C-H reactions via HAT can appear consistent with either classical "over-the-barrier" or "Bell-like tunneling correction" models. However, neither of these models is able to explain the observation of near-zero ΔEa values with many native enzymes that increase upon extrinsic or intrinsic perturbations to function. Instead, a full tunneling model has been developed that can account for the aggregate trends in the temp. dependence of the KIE. This model is reminiscent of Marcus-like theory for electron tunneling, with the addnl. incorporation of an H atom donor-acceptor distance (DAD) sampling term for effective wave function overlap; the role of the latter term is manifested in the exptl. detd. ΔEa. Three enzyme systems from this lab. that illustrate different aspects of HAT are presented: taurine dioxygenase, the dual copper β-monooxygenases, and soybean lipoxygenase (SLO). The latter provides a particularly compelling system for understanding the properties of hydrogen tunneling, showing systematic increases in ΔEa upon redn. in the size of hydrophobic residues both proximal and distal from the active site iron cofactor. Of note, recent ENDOR-based studies of enzyme-substrate complexes with SLO indicate an increase in DAD for mutants with increased ΔEa, observations that are inconsistent with "Bell-like correction" models. Overall, the surmounting kinetic and biophys. evidence corroborates a multidimensional approach for understanding HAT, offering a robust mechanistic explanation for the magnitude and trends of the KIE and ΔEa. Recent DFT and QM/MM computations on SLO are compared to the developed nonadiabatic anal. constructs, providing considerable insight into ground state structures and reactivity. However, QM/MM is unable to readily reproduce the small ΔEa values characteristic of native enzymes. Future theor. developments to capture these exptl. observations may necessitate a parsing of protein motions for local, substrate deuteration-sensitive modes from the larger conformational landscape, in the process providing deeper understanding of how native enzymes have evolved to transiently optimize their active site configurations.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhsF2jtbnP&md5=fa35a3eabc0c60f7131f911866f35e9d
          open URL
        31. 31
          Sharma, S. C.; Klinman, J. P. Kinetic Detection of Orthogonal Protein and Chemical Coordinates in Enzyme Catalysis: Double Mutants of Soybean Lipoxygenase. Biochemistry 2015, 54, 5447– 5456,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.biochem.5b00374
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          31
          Kinetic Detection of Orthogonal Protein and Chemical Coordinates in Enzyme Catalysis: Double Mutants of Soybean Lipoxygenase
          Sharma, Sudhir C.; Klinman, Judith P.
          Biochemistry (2015), 54 (35), 5447-5456CODEN: BICHAW; ISSN:0006-2960. (American Chemical Society)
          Soybean lipoxygenase-1 (SLO-1) is a paradigmatic enzyme system for studying the contribution of hydrogen tunneling to enzymic proton-coupled electron transfer processes. In this study, the impact of pairs of double mutants on the properties of SLO-1 is presented. Steady-state rates and their deuterium kinetic isotope effects (KIEs) have been measured for the bimol. reaction of enzyme with free substrate (kcat/Km) and compared to the unimol. rate const., kcat. A key kinetic finding is that the competitive KIEs on the second-order rate const. (kcat/Km) are all reduced from Dkcat and, despite large changes in rate and activation parameters, remain essentially unaltered under a variety of conditions. These data implicate a protein reaction coordinate that is orthogonal to the chem. reaction coordinate and controls the concn. of the active enzyme. This study introduces a new means to interrogate the alteration of conformational landscapes that can occur following site-specific mutagenesis.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtFejtbzE&md5=c6188bedfa5918ce1313d7e3df13e987
          open URL

          Hu, S.; Cattin-Ortola, J.; Munos, J. W.; Klinman, J. P. Hydrostatic Pressure Studies Distinguish Global from Local Protein Motions in C-H Activation by Soybean Lipoxygenase-1. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2016, 55, 9361– 9364,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201603592
          [Crossref], Google Scholar
          There is no corresponding record for this reference.
          open URL
        33. 33
          Offenbacher, A. R.; Hu, S.; Poss, E. M.; Carr, C. A. M.; Scouras, A. D.; Prigozhin, D. M.; Iavarone, A. T.; Palla, A.; Alber, T.; Fraser, J. S.; Klinman, J. P. Hydrogen–Deuterium Exchange of Lipoxygenase Uncovers a Relationship between Distal, Solvent Exposed Protein Motions and the Thermal Activation Barrier for Catalytic Proton-Coupled Electron Tunneling. ACS Cent. Sci. 2017, 3, 570– 579,  DOI: 10.1021/acscentsci.7b00142
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          33
          Hydrogen-Deuterium Exchange of Lipoxygenase Uncovers a Relationship between Distal, Solvent Exposed Protein Motions and the Thermal Activation Barrier for Catalytic Proton-Coupled Electron Tunneling
          Offenbacher, Adam R.; Hu, Shenshen; Poss, Erin M.; Carr, Cody A. M.; Scouras, Alexander D.; Prigozhin, Daniil M.; Iavarone, Anthony T.; Palla, Ali; Alber, Tom; Fraser, James S.; Klinman, Judith P.
          ACS Central Science (2017), 3 (6), 570-579CODEN: ACSCII; ISSN:2374-7951. (American Chemical Society)
          Defining specific pathways for efficient heat transfer from protein-solvent interfaces to their active sites represents one of the compelling and timely challenges in the quest for a phys. description of the origins of enzyme catalysis. Enzymic hydrogen tunneling reactions constitute excellent systems in which to validate exptl. approaches to this important question, given the inherent temp. independence of quantum mech. wave function overlap. Here, we present the application of H-D-exchange coupled to mass spectrometry toward the spatial resoln. of protein motions that can be related to enzymic catalytic parameters. Employing the proton-coupled electron transfer reaction of soybean lipoxygenase as proof of principle, we 1st corroborated the impact of active site mutation on increased local flexibility and 2nd, uncovered a solvent-exposed loop, 15-34 Å from the reactive ferric center whose temp.-dependent motions were demonstrated to mirror the enthalpic barrier for catalytic C-H bond cleavage. A network that connects this surface loop to the active site was structurally identified and supported by changes in kinetic parameters that resulted from site-specific mutations.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXpsFShu70%253D&md5=8881a7c990b8ce62dc0525656f09e563
          open URL
        34. 34
          Horitani, M.; Offenbacher, A. R.; Carr, C. A. M.; Yu, T.; Hoeke, V.; Cutsail, G. E.; Hammes-Schiffer, S.; Klinman, J. P.; Hoffman, B. M. C-13 Endor Spectroscopy of Lipoxygenase-Substrate Complexes Reveals the Structural Basis for C-H Activation by Tunneling. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2017, 139, 1984– 1997,  DOI: 10.1021/jacs.6b11856
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          34
          13C ENDOR Spectroscopy of Lipoxygenase-Substrate Complexes Reveals the Structural Basis for C-H Activation by Tunneling
          Horitani, Masaki; Offenbacher, Adam R.; Carr, Cody A. Marcus; Yu, Tao; Hoeke, Veronika; Cutsail, George E., III; Hammes-Schiffer, Sharon; Klinman, Judith P.; Hoffman, Brian M.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2017), 139 (5), 1984-1997CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          In enzymic C-H activation by H-tunneling, reduced barrier width is important for efficient H-wave-function overlap during catalysis. For native enzymes displaying non-adiabatic tunneling, the dominant reactive H donor-acceptor distance (DAD) is typically ∼2.7 Å, considerably shorter than normal van der Waals distances. Without a ground state substrate-bound structure for the prototypical nonadiabatic tunneling system, soybean lipoxygenase (SLO), it has remained unclear whether the requisite close tunneling distance occurs through an unusual ground-state active site arrangement or by thermally sampling conformational substates. Here, the authors introduced Mn2+ as a spin-probe surrogate for the SLO Fe-ion; x-ray diffraction showed that Mn-SLO was structurally faithful to native enzyme. 13C-ENDOR then revealed the locations of 13C10 and reactive 13C11 of linoleic acid relative to the metal; 1H-ENDOR and mol. dynamics simulations of the fully solvated SLO model using ENDOR-derived restraints gave addnl. metrical information. The resulting 3-dimensional representation of the SLO active site ground state contained a reactive conformer with a H DAD of ∼3.1 Å, approx. van der Waals contact, plus an inactive conformer with an even longer DAD, establishing that stochastic conformational sampling was required to achieve reactive tunneling geometries. Tunneling-impaired SLO variants showed increased DADs and variations in substrate positioning and rigidity, confirming previous kinetic and theor. predictions of such behavior. Overall, this investigation highlighted the (1) predictive power of non-adiabatic quantum treatments of proton-coupled electron transfer in SLO and (2) sensitivity of ENDOR probes to test, detect, and corroborate kinetically predicted trends in active site reactivity, and to reveal unexpected features of active site architecture.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhsVCisrg%253D&md5=899c3e1bdbd63671367a417ad6f28c19
          open URL
        35. 35
          Klinman, J. P.; Kohen, A. Hydrogen Tunneling Links Protein Dynamics to Enzyme Catalysis. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 2013, 82, 471– 496,  DOI: 10.1146/annurev-biochem-051710-133623
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          35
          Hydrogen tunneling links protein dynamics to enzyme catalysis
          Klinman, Judith P.; Kohen, Amnon
          Annual Review of Biochemistry (2013), 82 (), 471-496CODEN: ARBOAW; ISSN:0066-4154. (Annual Reviews)
          A review. The relationship between protein dynamics and function is a subject of considerable contemporary interest. Although protein motions are frequently obsd. during ligand binding and release steps, the contribution of protein motions to the catalysis of bond making/breaking processes is more difficult to probe and verify. Here, we show how the quantum mech. hydrogen tunneling assocd. with enzymic C-H bond cleavage provides a unique window into the necessity of protein dynamics for achieving optimal catalysis. Exptl. findings support a hierarchy of thermodynamically equilibrated motions that control the H-donor and -acceptor distance and active-site electrostatics, creating an ensemble of conformations suitable for H-tunneling. A possible extension of this view to Me transfer and other catalyzed reactions is also presented. The impact of understanding these dynamics on the conceptual framework for enzyme activity, inhibitor/drug design, and biomimetic catalyst design is likely to be substantial.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtFOqsr3I&md5=6e24730783d3737dc346d51c2a27d473
          open URL
        36. 36
          Kohen, A.; Cannio, R.; Bartolucci, S.; Klinman, J. P. Enzyme Dynamics and Hydrogen Tunnelling in a Thermophilic Alcohol Dehydrogenase. Nature 1999, 399, 496– 499,  DOI: 10.1038/20981
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          36
          Enzyme dynamics and hydrogen tunnelling in a thermophilic alcohol dehydrogenase
          Kohen, Amnon; Cannio, Raffaele; Bartolucci, Simonetta; Klinman, Judith P.
          Nature (London) (1999), 399 (6735), 496-499CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Macmillan Magazines)
          Biol. catalysts (enzymes) speed up reactions by many orders of magnitude using fundamental phys. processes to increase chem. reactivity. Hydrogen tunnelling has increasingly been found to contribute to enzyme reactions at room temp. Tunnelling is the phenomenon by which a particle transfers through a reaction barrier as a result of its wave-like property. In reactions involving small mols., the relative importance of tunnelling increases as the temp. is reduced. We have now investigated whether hydrogen tunnelling occurs at elevated temps. in a biol. system that functions physiol. under such conditions. Using a thermophilic alc. dehydrogenase (ADH), we find that hydrogen tunnelling makes a significant contribution at 65°C; this is analogous to previous findings with mesophilic ADH at 25°C. Contrary to predictions for tunnelling through a rigid barrier, the tunnelling with the thermophilic ADH decreases at and below room temp. These findings provide exptl. evidence for a role of thermally excited enzyme fluctuations in modulating enzyme-catalyzed bond cleavage.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXjvV2isLg%253D&md5=8515907854e2ac0724ce23b545beb9a3
          open URL
        37. 37
          Nagel, Z. D.; Dong, M.; Bahnson, B. J.; Klinman, J. P. Impaired Protein Conformational Landscapes as Revealed in Anomalous Arrhenius Prefactors. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2011, 108, 10520– 10525,  DOI: 10.1073/pnas.1104989108
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          37
          Impaired protein conformational landscapes as revealed in anomalous Arrhenius prefactors
          Nagel, Zachary D.; Dong, Ming; Bahnson, Brian J.; Klinman, Judith P.
          Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2011), 108 (26), 10520-10525, S10520/1-S10520/3CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
          A growing body of data supports a role for protein motion in enzyme catalysis. In particular, the ability of enzymes to sample catalytically relevant conformational substates has been invoked to model kinetic and spectroscopic data. However, direct exptl. links between rapidly interconverting conformations and the chem. steps of catalysis remain rare. We report here on the kinetic anal. and characterization of the hydride transfer step catalyzed by a series of mutant thermophilic alc. dehydrogenases (ht-ADH), presenting evidence for Arrhenius prefactor values that become enormously elevated above an expected value of approx. 1013 s-1 when the enzyme operates below its optimal temp. range. Restoration of normal Arrhenius behavior in the ht-ADH reaction occurs at elevated temps. A simple model, in which reduced temp. alters the ability of the ht-ADH variants to sample the catalytically relevant region of conformational space, can reproduce the available data. These findings indicate an impaired landscape that has been generated by the combined condition of reduced temp. and mutation at a single, active-site hydrophobic side chain. The broader implication is that optimal enzyme function requires the maintenance of a relatively smooth landscape that minimizes low energy traps.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXovFentLg%253D&md5=74b719a1094871a0de2ad383a0a9dcf3
          open URL
        38. 38
          Singh, P.; Sen, A.; Francis, K.; Kohen, A. Extension and Limits of the Network of Coupled Motions Correlated to Hydride Transfer in Dihydrofolate Reductase. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2014, 136, 2575– 2582,  DOI: 10.1021/ja411998h
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          38
          Extension and limits of the network of coupled motions correlated to hydride transfer in dihydrofolate reductase
          Singh, Priyanka; Sen, Arundhuti; Francis, Kevin; Kohen, Amnon
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136 (6), 2575-2582CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          Enzyme catalysis has been studied extensively, but the role of enzyme dynamics in the catalyzed chem. conversion is still an enigma. Dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) is often used as a model system to assess a network of coupled motions across the protein that may affect the catalyzed chem. transformation. Mol. dynamics simulations, quantum mech./mol. mech. studies, and bioinformatics studies have suggested the presence of a "global dynamic network" of residues in DHFR. Earlier studies of 2 DHFR distal mutants, G121V and M42W, indicated that these residues affect the chem. step synergistically. While this finding was in accordance with the concept of a network of functional motions across the protein, 2 residues do not constitute a network. To better define the extent and limits of the proposed network, the current work studied 2 remote residues predicted to be part of the same network: Trp-133 and Phe-125. The effect of mutations in these residues on the nature of the chem. step was examd. via measurements of the temp.-dependence of the intrinsic kinetic isotope effects (KIEs) and other kinetic parameters, and double mutants were used to tie the findings to Gly-121 and Met-42. The findings indicated that residue Phe-125, which was implicated by both calcns. and bioinformatic methods, is a part of the same global dynamic network as Gly-121 and Met-42, while Trp-133, implicated only by bioinformatics, is not. These findings extend the understanding of the proposed network and the relations between functional and genomic couplings. Delineating that network illuminates the need to consider remote residues and protein structural dynamics in the rational design of drugs and of biomimetic catalysts.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXht1eitbk%253D&md5=818cc6c8b59ac5f3804922bae67cdf4e
          open URL

          Francis, K.; Kohen, A. Protein Motions and the Activation of the Ch Bond Catalyzed by Dihydrofolate Reductase. Curr. Opin. Chem. Biol. 2014, 21, 19– 24,  DOI: 10.1016/j.cbpa.2014.03.009
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          39
          Protein motions and the activation of the C-H bond catalyzed by dihydrofolate reductase
          Francis, Kevin; Kohen, Amnon
          Current Opinion in Chemical Biology (2014), 21 (), 19-24CODEN: COCBF4; ISSN:1367-5931. (Elsevier B.V.)
          A review. The role of protein motions in enzymic C-H → C transfer is an area of great contemporary debate. An effective tool in probing such a role is the temp. dependence of the intrinsic kinetic isotope effects for the enzyme-catalyzed reaction. The outcome of those expts. is interpreted within the context of phenomenol. Marcus-like models of hydrogen tunneling. Here, the authors focus on recent studies of dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) and how the role of protein motions in the catalyzed reaction has been demonstrated. The motions in DHFR are controlled by local effects of active site residues, global effects involving remote residues across the enzyme, and appear to be preserved during the evolution of the enzyme from bacteria to humans.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXht1KqtrzP&md5=204e9deea02d9ebdcab2d91ff37eb219
          open URL
        40. 40
          Loveridge, E. J.; Tey, L. H.; Behiry, E. M.; Dawson, W. M.; Evans, R. M.; Whittaker, S. B.; Gunther, U. L.; Williams, C.; Crump, M. P.; Allemann, R. K. The Role of Large-Scale Motions in Catalysis by Dihydrofolate Reductase. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2011, 133, 20561– 20570,  DOI: 10.1021/ja208844j
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          40
          The Role of Large-Scale Motions in Catalysis by Dihydrofolate Reductase
          Loveridge, E. Joel; Tey, Lai-Hock; Behiry, Enas M.; Dawson, William M.; Evans, Rhiannon M.; Whittaker, Sara B.-M.; Gunther, Ulrich L.; Williams, Christopher; Crump, Matthew P.; Allemann, Rudolf K.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2011), 133 (50), 20561-20570CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          Dihydrofolate reductase has long been used as a model system to study the coupling of protein motions to enzymic hydride transfer. By studying environmental effects on hydride transfer in dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) from the cold-adapted bacterium Moritella profunda (MpDHFR) and comparing the flexibility of this enzyme to that of DHFR from Escherichia coli (EcDHFR), we demonstrate that factors that affect large-scale (i.e., long-range, but not necessarily large amplitude) protein motions have no effect on the kinetic isotope effect on hydride transfer or its temp. dependence, although the rates of the catalyzed reaction are affected. Hydrogen/deuterium exchange studies by NMR-spectroscopy show that MpDHFR is a more flexible enzyme than EcDHFR. NMR expts. with EcDHFR in the presence of cosolvents suggest differences in the conformational ensemble of the enzyme. The fact that enzymes from different environmental niches and with different flexibilities display the same behavior of the kinetic isotope effect on hydride transfer strongly suggests that, while protein motions are important to generate the reaction ready conformation, an optimal conformation with the correct electrostatics and geometry for the reaction to occur, they do not influence the nature of the chem. step itself; large-scale motions do not couple directly to hydride transfer proper in DHFR.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhsVaisLnF&md5=d97e59da403072e939b6dc97ef5955c4
          open URL
        41. 41
          Fraser, J. S.; van den Bedem, H.; Samelson, A. J.; Lang, P. T.; Holton, J. M.; Echols, N.; Alber, T. Accessing Protein Conformational Ensembles Using Room-Temperature X-Ray Crystallography. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2011, 108, 16247– 16252,  DOI: 10.1073/pnas.1111325108
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          41
          Accessing protein conformational ensembles using room-temperature X-ray crystallography
          Fraser, James S.; van den Bedemb, H. Enry; Samelson, Avi J.; Lang, P. Therese; Holton, James M.; Echols, Nathaniel; Alber, Tom
          Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2011), 108 (39), 16247-16252, S16247/1-S16247/6CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
          Modern protein crystal structures are based nearly exclusively on X-ray data collected at cryogenic temps. (generally 100 K). The cooling process is thought to introduce little bias in the functional interpretation of structural results, because cryogenic temps. minimally perturb the overall protein backbone fold. In contrast, here we show that flash cooling biases previously hidden structural ensembles in protein crystals. By analyzing available data for 30 different proteins using new computational tools for electron-d. sampling, model refinement, and mol. packing anal., we found that crystal cryocooling remodels the conformational distributions of more than 35% of side chains and eliminates packing defects necessary for functional motions. In the signaling switch protein, H-Ras, an allosteric network consistent with fluctuations detected in soln. by NMR was uncovered in the room-temp., but not the cryogenic, electron-d. maps. These results expose a bias in structural databases toward smaller, overpacked, and unrealistically unique models. Monitoring room-temp. conformational ensembles by X-ray crystallog. can reveal motions crucial for catalysis, ligand binding, and allosteric regulation.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXht1Kmtb%252FO&md5=3208af982595fe975437459890bcb436
          open URL

          Keedy, D. A.; Kenner, L. R.; Warkentin, M.; Woldeyes, R. A.; Hopkins, J. B.; Thompson, M. C.; Brewster, A. S.; Van Benschoten, A. H.; Baxter, E. L.; Uervirojnangkoorn, M.; McPhillips, S.           Keedy, D. A.; van den Bedem, H.; Sivak, D. A.; Petsko, G. A.; Ringe, D.; Wilson, M. A.; Fraser, J. S. Crystal Cryocooling Distorts Conformational Heterogeneity in a Model Michaelis Complex of Dhfr. Structure 2014, 22, 899– 910,  DOI: 10.1016/j.str.2014.04.016
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          43
          Crystal cryocooling distorts conformational heterogeneity in a model Michaelis complex of DHFR
          Keedy, Daniel A.; van den Bedem, Henry; Sivak, David A.; Petsko, Gregory A.; Ringe, Dagmar; Wilson, Mark A.; Fraser, James S.
          Structure (Oxford, United Kingdom) (2014), 22 (6), 899-910CODEN: STRUE6; ISSN:0969-2126. (Elsevier Ltd.)
          Most macromol. X-ray structures are detd. from cryocooled crystals, but it is unclear whether cryocooling distorts functionally relevant flexibility. Here we compare independently acquired pairs of high-resoln. data sets of a model Michaelis complex of dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), collected by sep. groups at both room and cryogenic temps. These data sets allow us to isolate the differences between exptl. procedures and between temps. Our analyses of multiconformer models and time-averaged ensembles suggest that cryocooling suppresses and otherwise modifies side-chain and main-chain conformational heterogeneity, quenching dynamic contact networks. Despite some idiosyncratic differences, most changes from room temp. to cryogenic temp. are conserved and likely reflect temp.-dependent solvent remodeling. Both cryogenic data sets point to addnl. conformations not evident in the corresponding room temp. data sets, suggesting that cryocooling does not merely trap preexisting conformational heterogeneity. Our results demonstrate that crystal cryocooling consistently distorts the energy landscape of DHFR, a paragon for understanding functional protein dynamics.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXpslCgsb4%253D&md5=33df728ed5ba360d47dd06e46332b132
          open URL

          Slappendel, S.; Veldink, G. A.; Vliegenthart, J. F.; Aasa, R.; Malmstrom, B. G. Epr Spectroscopy of Soybean Lipoxygenase-1. Description and Quantification of the High-Spin Fe(Iii) Signals. Biochim. Biophys. Acta, Protein Struct. 1981, 667, 77– 86,  DOI: 10.1016/0005-2795(81)90068-4

          EPR spectroscopy of soybean lipoxygenase-1. Description and quantification of the high-spin iron(III) signals
          Slappendel, Steven; Veldink, Gerrit A.; Vliegenthart, Johannes F. G.; Aasa, Roland; Malmstroem, Bo G.
          Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, Protein Structure (1981), 667 (1), 77-86CODEN: BBPTBH; ISSN:0005-2795.
          The interaction of soybean lipoxygenase-1 with 13-LS-hydroperoxy-9-cis,11-trans-octadecadienoic acid, the product of the enzymic dioxygenation of linoleic acid, results in the formation of either a yellow or purple enzyme, depending on the amt. of product used. The compn. of the high-spin Fe(III) signals in the ESR spectra of both enzyme forms was studied and the amt. of EPR-visible Fe detd. by integration and simulation. Sets of g values of the species building up the high-spin Fe(III) signal around g 6 are derived from both 3rd-order perturbation calcn. and exact numerical diagonalization of the spin Hamiltonian describing the system. The Fe in the native, colorless enzyme is almost ESR-nondetectable. The yellow form of the enzyme shows a complex ESR signal around g 6 which consists of contributions of ≥3 species with different ligand symmetry. The signal corresponds to ∼75% of the total Fe content. The g 6 signal of the purple Fe(III) enzyme corresponds roughly to the same amt. of Fe but the ratio between the different species is not the same as in the yellow enzyme. This enzyme form also shows an addnl. g 4.3 signal with a large amplitude but a relatively low integrated intensity (∼10% of the total Fe content). The results are consistent with the suggested mechanism of the catalytic function of Fe in lipoxygenase based on qual. ESR results.

          Chasteen, N. D.; Grady, J. K.; Skorey, K. I.; Neden, K. J.; Riendeau, D.; Percival, M. D. Characterization of the Non-Heme Iron Center of Human 5-Lipoxygenase by Electron Paramagnetic Resonance, Fluorescence, and Ultraviolet-Visible Spectroscopy: Redox Cycling between Ferrous and Ferric States.           [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          45
          Characterization of the non-heme iron center of human 5-lipoxygenase by electron paramagnetic resonance, fluorescence, and ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy: Redox cycling between ferrous and ferric states
          Chasteen, N. Dennis; Grady, John K.; Skorey, Kathryn I.; Neden, Kevin J.; Riendeau, Denis; Percival, M. David
          Biochemistry (1993), 32 (37), 9763-71CODEN: BICHAW; ISSN:0006-2960.
          Purified human 5-lipoxygenase, a non-heme iron contg. enzyme, has been characterized by ESR, UV-visible and fluorescence spectroscopy. As isolated, the enzyme is largely in the ferrous state and shows a weak X-band EPR signal extending from 0 to 700 G at 15 K, tentatively ascribed to integer spin Fe(II). Titrn. of the protein with 13-HPOD (13-hydroperoxyoctadecadienoic acid) generates a strong multicomponent EPR signal in the g' ≈ 6 region, a yellow color assocd. with an increased absorption between 310 and 450 nm (ε330nm = 2400 M-1 cm-), and a 17% decrease in the intrinsic protein fluorescence. The multiple component nature of the g' ≈ 6 signal indicates that the metal center in its oxidized state exists in more than one but related forms. The g' ≈ 6 EPR signal and the yellow color reach a max. when approx. 1 mol of 13-HPOD is added/mol of iron; the resultant EPR spectrum accounts quant. for all of the iron in the protein with a signal at g' = 4.3 representing less than 3% of the total iron in the majority of samples. Addn. of a hydroxyurea reducing agent abolished the g' ≈ 6 signal and yellow color of the protein and also reversed the decrease in fluorescence caused by the oxidant 13-HPOD. The results indicate that the g' ≈ 6 EPR signal, the yellow color, and the decreased fluorescence are assocd. with the formation of the Fe(III) form of the enzyme. The spectroscopic data demonstrate that the Fe(III) center of 5-lipoxygenase can be redox-cycled, consistent with its postulated role in the mechanism of oxidn. of unsatd. fatty acids to hydroperoxides. Studies using the irreversible inhibitor 4-nitrocatechol, which binds to the ferric form of the enzyme, are also consistent with the redox cycling of the iron and demonstrate that the oxidn. state of the enzyme influences both its functional and phys. properties.
          >> More from SciFinder ®

          Nelson, M. J.; Brennan, B. A.; Chase, D. B.; Cowling, R. A.; Grove, G. N.; Scarrow, R. C. Structure and Kinetics of Formation of Catechol Complexes of Ferric Soybean Lipoxygenase-1. Biochemistry 1995, 34, 15219– 15229,  DOI: 10.1021/bi00046a030
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          48
          Structure and Kinetics of Formation of Catechol Complexes of Ferric Soybean Lipoxygenase-1
          Nelson, Mark J.; Brennan, Bridget A.; Chase, D. Bruce; Cowling, Rebecca A.; Grove, Geoffrey N.; Scarrow, Robert C.
          Biochemistry (1995), 34 (46), 15219-29CODEN: BICHAW; ISSN:0006-2960. (American Chemical Society)
          Ferric soybean lipoxygenase forms stable complexes with 4-substituted catechols. The structure of the complex between the enzyme and 3,4-dihydroxybenzonitrile has been studied by resonance Raman, ESR, visible, and x-ray spectroscopies. It is a bidentate iron-catecholate complex with at least one water ligand. The kinetics of formation of complexes between lipoxygenase and 3,4-dihydroxybenzonitrile and 3,4-dihydroxyacetophenone have been studied by stopped-flow spectroscopy. The data are consistent with two kinetically distinct, reversible steps. The pH dependence of the first step suggests that the substrate for the reaction is the catechol monoanion. When these results are combined, plausible mechanisms for the complexation reaction are suggested.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXovFOjtbc%253D&md5=87c812d60f08b04d97e80f7833b9acb9

          49
          Structural and Thermochemical Characterization of Lipoxygenase-Catechol Complexes
          Pham, Chau; Jankun, Jerzy; Skrzypczak-Jankun, Ewa; Flowers, Robert A., II; Funk, Max O. Jr.
          Biochemistry (1998), 37 (51), 17952-17957CODEN: BICHAW; ISSN:0006-2960. (American Chemical Society)
          A complex between native, iron(II) soybean lipoxygenase 3 and 4-nitrocatechol, a known inhibitor of the enzyme, has been detected by isothermal titrn. calorimetry and characterized by X-ray crystallog. The compd. moors in the central cavity of the protein close to the essential iron atom, but not in a bonding arrangement with it. The iron ligands experience a significant rearrangement upon formation of the complex relative to their positions in the native enzyme; a water mol. becomes bound to iron in the complex, and one histidine ligand moves away from the iron to become involved in a hydrogen bonding interaction with the catechol. These changes in position result in a trigonal pyramid coordination geometry for iron in the complex. Mol. modeling and force field calcns. predict more than one stable complex between 4-nitrocatechol and the central cavity of lipoxygenase 3, but the interaction having the small mol. in the same orientation as the one found in the crystal structure was the most favorable. These observations reveal specific details of the interaction between lipoxygenase and a small mol. and raise the possibility that changes in the ligand environment of the iron atom could be a feature of the product activation reaction or the catalytic mechanism.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXns1Ckt7w%253D&md5=56a972ac677763307d6cc4cb4dc4bf0b
          open URL
        50. 50
          Nelson, M. J. Catecholate Complexes of Ferric Soybean Lipoxygenase-1. Biochemistry 1988, 27, 4273– 4278,  DOI: 10.1021/bi00412a011
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          50
          Catecholate complexes of ferric soybean lipoxygenase 1
          Nelson, Mark J.
          Biochemistry (1988), 27 (12), 4273-8CODEN: BICHAW; ISSN:0006-2960.
          Lipoxygenases are non-heme Fe-contg. enzymes that catalyze the peroxidn. of unsatd. fatty acids contg. 1,4-dienes to yield 1,3-diene-5-hydroperoxides. The mechanism is thought to include a ferrous-bis(allyl) radical complex as an intermediate. The complexes formed between ferric soybean lipoxygenase 1 and a series of 4-substituted catechols were used to study the Fe environment. At pH 7, substituted catechols with sufficiently electron-withdrawing substituents (e.g., 3,4-dihydroxybenzonitrile, 3,4-dihydroxybenzaldehyde) formed stable complexes that were best viewed as Fe3+-catechol2- on the basis of the positions and no. of charge-transfer bands in their visible spectra. Catecholes with less electron-withdrawing substituents (e.g., catechol, 2,3-dihydroxynaphthalene) efficiently reduced the Fe. More of the substituted catechols were competent to reduce the Fe at pH 8, and at pH 9 all of the catechols tested reduced ferric lipoxygenase. Ests. of the pH-dependent oxidn. potentials of the catechols suggested that the redn. potential of Fe(III) in lipoxygenase was approx. +0.6 V (relative to the normal H electrode) at pH 7-9. These catechols were slow-binding inhibitors of lipoxygenase at pH 7, with final Ki values of 6-100 μM. The magnitude of Ki did not correlate with the electron-withdrawing character of the substituents; presumably, other effects, such as charge and polarity, are more important.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1cXktF2gs7g%253D&md5=e5105f78692146d428acb7eca9a4c310
          open URL
        51. 51
          Kemal, C.; Louis-Flamberg, P.; Krupinski-Olsen, R.; Shorter, A. L. Reductive Inactivation of Soybean Lipoxygenase 1 by Catechols: A Possible Mechanism for Regulation of Lipoxygenase Activity. Biochemistry 1987, 26, 7064– 7072,  DOI: 10.1021/bi00396a031
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          51
          Reductive inactivation of soybean lipoxygenase 1 by catechols: a possible mechanism for regulation of lipoxygenase activity
          Kemal, Cemal; Louis-Flamberg, Pearl; Krupinski-Olsen, Rosita; Shorter, Andrew L.
          Biochemistry (1987), 26 (22), 7064-72CODEN: BICHAW; ISSN:0006-2960.
          Nordihydroguaiaretic acid (NDGA), one of the most efficient inhibitors of lipoxygenases, is shown, by EPR, CD, and fluorescence studies, to reduce the catalytically active ferric soybean lipoxygenase 1 (Eox) to the inactive ferrous form (Ered). In decreasing order of reactivity, the following also reduced Eox: catechol > hydroquinone > esculetin ≈ norepinephrine > 2,6-di-tert-butyl-4-methylphenol > caffeic acid > α-tocopherol > dithiothreitol. The redn. of Eox by NDGA (k = 8.1 × 106 M-1 s-1, pH 9.0, 25°) was almost as fast as the Eox-catalyzed conversion of linoleate (LH) to 13(S)-hydroperoxy-9(Z),11(E)-octadecadienoate (LOOH) and the oxidn. of Ered by LOOH to give Eox. Thus, NDGA can efficiently inhibit the Eox-catalyzed conversion of LH to LOOH by reducing Eox to the inactive Ered, thereby diminishing the turnover rate. Lipoxygenase catalyzed the oxidn. of NDGA by LOOH at a rate that was consistent with the independently detd. rate const. for the redn. of Eox by NDGA. All 4 reducing equiv from the 2 catechol groups in NDGA could be utilized in the redn. of Eox, leading to the consumption of 4 mol LOOH/mol NDGA initially present. Because the catalytically inactive Ered was oxidized by fatty acid hydroperoxides (e.g., LOOH) to give the active Eox, reducing agents such as NDGA were most effective as lipoxygenase inhibitors at low hydroperoxide concns. The results suggested that in vivo, where lipid hydroperoxides are maintained at low steady-state levels, redn. of lipoxygenase from the ferric to ferrous state may be important in the regulation of lipoxygenase activity and hence leukotriene biosynthesis.

          Bellissent-Funel, M. C.; Hassanali, A.; Havenith, M.; Henchman, R.; Pohl, P.; Sterpone, F.; van der Spoel, D.; Xu, Y.; Garcia, A. E. Water Determines the Structure and Dynamics of Proteins. Chem. Rev. 2016, 116, 7673– 97,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.5b00664
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          53
          Water Determines the Structure and Dynamics of Proteins
          Bellissent-Funel, Marie-Claire; Hassanali, Ali; Havenith, Martina; Henchman, Richard; Pohl, Peter; Sterpone, Fabio; van der Spoel, David; Xu, Yao; Garcia, Angel E.
          Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2016), 116 (13), 7673-7697CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
          Water is an essential participant in the stability, structure, dynamics, and function of proteins and other biomols. Thermodynamically, changes in the aq. environment affect the stability of biomols. Structurally, water participates chem. in the catalytic function of proteins and nucleic acids and phys. in the collapse of the protein chain during folding through hydrophobic collapse and mediates binding through the hydrogen bond in complex formation. Water is a partner that slaves the dynamics of proteins, and water interaction with proteins affect their dynamics. Here we provide a review of the exptl. and computational advances over the past decade in understanding the role of water in the dynamics, structure, and function of proteins. We focus on the combination of X-ray and neutron crystallog., NMR, terahertz spectroscopy, mass spectroscopy, thermodn., and computer simulations to reveal how water assist proteins in their function. The recent advances in computer simulations and the enhanced sensitivity of exptl. tools promise major advances in the understanding of protein dynamics, and water surely will be a protagonist.

          55
          Dissecting the Hydrophobic Effect on the Molecular Level: The Role of Water, Enthalpy, and Entropy in Ligand Binding to Thermolysin
          Biela, Adam; Nasief, Nader N.; Betz, Michael; Heine, Andreas; Hangauer, David; Klebe, Gerhard
          Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2013), 52 (6), 1822-1828CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          The hydrophobic effect is assocd. with the successive replacement of water mols. in the binding site of a protein by hydrophobic groups of the ligand. Although the hydrophobic effect is assumed to be entropy-driven, large changes in enthalpy and entropy are obsd. with the model system thermolysin. Structural changes in the binding features of the water mols. ultimately det. the thermodn. of the hydrophobic effect.

          Snyder, P. W.; Mecinovic, J.; Moustakas, D. T.; Thomas, S. W., 3rd; Harder, M.; Mack, E. T.; Lockett, M. R.; Heroux, A.; Sherman, W.; Whitesides, G. M. Mechanism of the Hydrophobic Effect in the Biomolecular Recognition of Arylsulfonamides by Carbonic Anhydrase. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2011, 108, 17889– 17894,  DOI: 10.1073/pnas.1114107108
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          56
          Mechanism of the hydrophobic effect in the biomolecular recognition of arylsulfonamides by carbonic anhydrase
          Snyder, Phillip W.; Mecinoviv, Jasmin; Moustakas, Demetri T.; Thomas, Samuel W., III; Harder, Michael; Mack, Eric T.; Lockett, Matthew R.; Heroux, Annie; Sherman, Woody; Whitesides, George M.
          Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2011), 108 (44), 17889-17894, S17889/1-S17889/10CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
          The hydrophobic effect - a rationalization of the insoly. of nonpolar mols. in water-is centrally important to biomol. recognition. Despite extensive research devoted to the hydrophobic effect, its mol. mechanisms remain controversial, and there are still no reliably predictive models for its role in protein-ligand binding. Here we describe a particularly well-defined system of protein and ligands - carbonic anhydrase and a series of structurally homologous heterocyclic arom. sulfonamides - that we use to characterize hydrophobic interactions thermodynamically and structurally. In binding to this structurally rigid protein, a set of ligands (also defined to be structurally rigid) shows the expected gain in binding free energy as hydrophobic surface area is added. Isothermal titrn. calorimetry demonstrates that enthalpy dets. these increases in binding affinity, and that changes in the heat capacity of binding are. neg. X-ray crystallog. and mol. dynamics simulations are compatible with the proposal that the differences in binding between the homologous ligands stem from changes in the no. and organization of water mols. localized in the active site in the bound complexes, rather than (or perhaps in addn. to) release of structured water from the apposed hydrophobic surfaces. These results support the hypothesis that structured water mols. - including both the mols. of water displaced by the ligands and those reorganized upon ligand binding - det. the thermodn. of binding of these ligands at the active site of the protein. Hydrophobic effects in various contexts have different structural and thermodn. origins, although all may be manifestations of the differences in characteristics of bulk water and water close to hydrophobic surfaces.

          Chervenak, M. C.; Toone, E. J. A Direct Measure of the Contribution of Solvent Reorganization to the Enthalpy of Binding. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1994, 116, 10533– 10539,  DOI: 10.1021/ja00102a021
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          57
          A Direct Measure of the Contribution of Solvent Reorganization to the Enthalpy of Binding
          Chervenak, Mary C.; Toone, Eric J.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (1994), 116 (23), 10533-9CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
          The thermodn. of assocn. of several binding systems, including protein-carbohydrate, small mol.-small mol., protein-peptide, and protein-nucleic acid, were evaluated calorimetrically in light and heavy water. In every case, the enthalpy of binding in D2O was decreased relative to that in H2O: the differences range from 400 to 1800 cal mol-∞1. A compensating change in ΔS left the free energy of binding virtually unchanged in each case. A strong correlation between the differential enthalpy of binding and ΔCp for binding was obsd., with a slope of 5 K. An anal. of the obsd. effect utilizing a Born-Haber thermodn. cycle shows that the measured decrease in enthalpy represents approx. 10% of the binding enthalpy arising from solvent reorganization. For the range of systems investigated, solvent reorganization provides 25-100% of the obsd. enthalpy of binding.

          Barillari, C.; Taylor, J.; Viner, R.; Essex, J. W. Classification of Water Molecules in Protein Binding Sites. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2007, 129, 2577– 2587,  DOI: 10.1021/ja066980q
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          58
          Classification of Water Molecules in Protein Binding Sites
          Barillari, Caterina; Taylor, Justine; Viner, Russell; Essex, Jonathan W.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (9), 2577-2587CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          Water mols. play a crucial role in mediating the interaction between a ligand and a macromol. receptor. An understanding of the nature and role of each water mol. in the active site of a protein could greatly increase the efficiency of rational drug design approaches: if the propensity of a water mol. for displacement can be detd., then synthetic effort may be most profitably applied to the design of specific ligands with the displacement of this water mol. in mind. In this paper, a thermodn. anal. of water mols. in the binding sites of six proteins, each complexed with a no. of inhibitors, is presented. Two classes of water mols. were identified: those conserved and not displaced by any of the ligands, and those that are displaced by some ligands. The abs. binding free energies of 54 water mols. were calcd. using the double decoupling method, with replica exchange thermodn. integration in Monte Carlo simulations. It was found that conserved water mols. are on av. more tightly bound than displaced water mols. In addn., Bayesian statistics is used to calc. the probability that a particular water mol. may be displaced by an appropriately designed ligand, given the calcd. binding free energy of the water mol. This approach therefore allows the numerical assessment of whether or not a given water mol. should be targeted for displacement as part of a rational drug design strategy.

          Abel, R.; Young, T.; Farid, R.; Berne, B. J.; Friesner, R. A. Role of the Active-Site Solvent in the Thermodynamics of Factor Xa Ligand Binding. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2008, 130, 2817– 2831,  DOI: 10.1021/ja0771033
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          59
          Role of the Active-Site Solvent in the Thermodynamics of Factor Xa Ligand Binding
          Abel, Robert; Young, Tom; Farid, Ramy; Berne, Bruce J.; Friesner, Richard A.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (9), 2817-2831CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          Understanding the underlying physics of the binding of small-mol. ligands to protein active sites is a key objective of computational chem. and biol. It is widely believed that displacement of water mols. from the active site by the ligand is a principal (if not the dominant) source of binding free energy. Although continuum theories of hydration are routinely used to describe the contributions of the solvent to the binding affinity of the complex, it is still an unsettled question as to whether or not these continuum solvation theories describe the underlying mol. physics with sufficient accuracy to reliably rank the binding affinities of a set of ligands for a given protein. Here we develop a novel, computationally efficient descriptor of the contribution of the solvent to the binding free energy of a small mol. and its assocd. receptor that captures the effects of the ligand displacing the solvent from the protein active site with at. detail. This descriptor quant. predicts (R2 = 0.81) the binding free energy differences between congeneric ligand pairs for the test system factor Xa, elucidates phys. properties of the active site solvent that appear to be missing in most continuum theories of hydration, and identifies several features of the hydration of the factor Xa active site relevant to the structure-activity relationship of its inhibitors.
